â€¢Ginger Rogers and her second husband, Lew Ayres, are photographed on their wedding day in California, 1934. â¤ï¸

In 1933, Rogers was already a successful actress in Hollywood, having starred in a variety of films for RKO when she was signed on to appear in the Murray Roth comedy, â€œDonâ€™t Bet on Love.â€

Her costar in the film was Lew Ayres and shortly after filming began in mid 1933, the two actors began seeing one another.

After around one year of dating in the summer of 1934, Rogers and Ayres became engaged and on November 13, 1934, the couple married at a lavish ceremony inside of the Little Church of the Flowers in Glendale, California. 

Following their wedding, the couple were quickly back at work with Rogers making the second of ten pictures with Fred Astaire, â€œThe Gay Divorcee,â€ while Ayres started production on the Janet Gaynor film, â€œState Fair.â€

Both films would be successful however by the time of their release, both Rogers and Ayres had realized they were polar opposites and before long, they started to grow apart.

At this time, Ayres had started drinking heavily which irked the heavily religious Rogers and adding to this, Ayres had also demanded that she sign a prenup which kept their property separate and led to frequent arguments erupting between the pair. 

By 1936, the couple were living separate lives and it was around this time that Rogers struck up many relationships with different men including married actor, George Stevens and aviation tycoon, Howard Hughes. 

Though Ayres attempted a reconciliation with Rogers in the late 1930s, their marriage wasnâ€™t to last and ended in divorce on March 7, 1940.

Following the marriage both went on to remarry, Rogers to Jack Briggs in 1943 and Ayres to Diana Hall in 1964. While Rogers marriage to Briggs lasted only six years, Ayres and Diana would remain together for over three decades before his death in 1996 at the age of 88.

Rogers lived out the remainder of her life in California before passing away in 1995 at the age of 83. Today, she is buried in Oakwood Memorial Cemetery in Los Angeles.".
